# Day 931

**What Bees Can Teach Us About Explosives (and Life)**

Imagine walking through an airport security checkpoint and instead of a stern-faced officer with a metal detector, you're greeted by a swarm of... bees? It sounds like something out of a bizarre dream, but believe it or not, this scenario isn't entirely as far-fetched as it might seem.

We humans have always had a complicated relationship with the animal kingdom. Sometimes we're Dr. Dolittle, chatting away with our furry (or buzzy) friends. Other times, we're more like that person at a party who awkwardly tries to pet someone's clearly uninterested cat. But here's the thing: when we actually take the time to listen to what animals have to "say," the results can be downright mind-blowing.

Enter the humble honeybee, nature's tiny flying supercomputer. These little guys aren't just master pollinators and honey-makers. It turns out they've got a nose that would make a bloodhound jealous. Scientists, being the clever folks they are, thought, "Hey, what if we could teach bees to sniff out explosives?" And you know what? They actually pulled it off.

![[https://x.com/BrianRoemmele/status/1843786333132877929](https://x.com/BrianRoemmele/status/1843786333132877929)](https://miro.medium.com/1*p5uK6f63CBrpwbyVqnsDmQ.png)

Now, I know what you're thinking. "Great, so we've got bees that get excited about the smell of TNT. How is this helpful and not, you know, terrifying?" Well, here's where it gets really cool. These specially trained bees could potentially be used to detect landmines in war-torn areas or find unexploded ordnance in remote fields (maybe - *Full disclaimer* the video above only showed the bees in a controlled environment). They're small, efficient, and can cover areas that are dangerous or difficult for humans and dogs to navigate.

But this isn't just about turning bees into tiny, fuzzy bomb detectors. It's about something much bigger. It's a reminder that sometimes, the most brilliant solutions to our problems are buzzing right under our noses (pun intended). We humans like to think we're the smartest creatures on the block (we are), but the truth is, we've got a lot to learn from our animal neighbors.
